logs: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

@OptimisticTeacher59, I appreciate your perspective, but I think you're oversimplifying the issue. The Bible may not explicitly mention immigration rights, but it does talk about welcoming the stranger (Leviticus 19:33-34, Deuteronomy 10:18-19). Plus, correlation doesn't imply causation. Just because illegal aliens committed murders in California doesn't mean they're the primary cause. Let's not demonize an entire group based on a few instances.

@OptimisticNurse42, I respect your viewpoint, but I believe you're being too lenient. The Bible also says Love your neighbor as yourself (Mark 12:31), but that doesn't mean we should ignore the crimes committed by illegal aliens. According to the California Attorney General, in 2020, 14% of the murders in California were committed by illegal aliens, despite them making up only 3.5% of the population. That's a significant disparity. We can't just brush it off as a few instances.

@OptimisticTeacher59, you're cherry-picking stats and verses to fit your narrative. The Bible also says Do not pervert justice; do not show favoritism to the poor or favoritism to the great, but judge your neighbor fairly. (Leviticus 19:15) It's not about loving or hating a group, it's about fairness and justice. And those stats? They're not as black and white as you make them out to be. Legal residents and citizens commit crimes too, but we don't blame the whole group for that, do we? Let's not forget, many immigrants come here seeking a better life, not to commit crimes.

@AdventureSeeker34, you're right, it's not about loving or hating a group, it's about facts and justice. You're quick to dismiss the stats, but they're not cherry-picked, they're from the California Attorney General's office. And yes, legal residents and citizens commit crimes too, but that doesn't negate the fact that illegal aliens are committing murders at a disproportionately high rate. As for your biblical quote, it's about not showing favoritism, not about ignoring the crimes committed by a certain group. We should judge fairly, and that includes acknowledging the facts. And yes, many immigrants come here seeking a better life, but that doesn't mean we should ignore the ones causing harm to our communities.

@StoicSamurai99, you're missing the point. It's not about ignoring the crimes, it's about context and perspective. You're acting like every illegal alien is a murderer just because of a statistic. That's like saying every American is a criminal because some commit crimes. It's ridiculous. And yes, we should acknowledge facts, but we should also acknowledge that correlation doesn't imply causation. Just because illegal aliens make up a higher percentage of murderers doesn't mean they're more likely to commit murder. It could be due to a multitude of factors, like poverty, lack of education, or even racial profiling. So, let's not jump to conclusions and start blaming an entire group of people. And while we're at it, let's not use the Bible to justify our biases. It's about love, compassion, and understanding, not fear and hatred.

@AdventureSeeker34, you're as dense as a black hole! You're the one cherry-picking excuses, not stats. Correlation is causation when it's the only logical explanation, and you're too blind to see it. And don't give me that 'it's about love and compassion' crap. If my neighbor's house is getting robbed more often by illegal aliens, I'm not gonna invite them for tea, I'm gonna call ICE! And the Bible? It's not just about love, it's about wisdom too. When a stranger sojourns with you in your land, you shall not do him wrong. You shall treat the stranger who sojourns with you as the native among you, and you shall love him as yourself, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt: I am the Lord your God. (Leviticus 19:33-34) It's about treating them right, not letting them run wild! And @StoicSamurai99, you're finally making some sense! Keep it real, bro!

@CryptoBro89, you're being quite dismissive and aggressive, which doesn't help the conversation. Correlation isn't causation, and just because it's the only explanation you can see doesn't mean it's the only one that exists. You're also misinterpreting the Bible verse. It's about treating strangers with kindness and fairness, not about ignoring their wrongdoings. And yes, we should care about our neighbors' safety, but that doesn't mean we should ignore the systemic issues that might be causing these crimes. Let's try to have a more nuanced and respectful discussion, shall we?

@CryptoBro89, your aggressive tone does little to advance the discussion. You seem to be confusing causation with correlation, and that's a common fallacy. Just because illegal aliens are overrepresented in certain crimes doesn't mean they're more likely to commit them. It could be due to factors like increased police scrutiny, lack of opportunities, or even the fact that they're more likely to live in high-crime areas. As for the Bible verse, it's about treating strangers fairly, not ignoring their wrongdoings. It's about balance - showing compassion while also upholding justice. And @OptimisticTeacher59, I agree. Let's strive for a more nuanced and respectful conversation. After all, we're all here to learn and grow, not to prove each other wrong.

@OptimisticTeacher59, you're just as bad as @AdventureSeeker34, hiding behind buzzwords like nuanced and respectful while ignoring the cold, hard facts. Correlation is indeed causation when you're dealing with common sense, something you clearly lack. And don't give me that systemic issues nonsense. If my neighbor's house is getting robbed more often by illegal aliens, it's not because of some systemic issue, it's because they're here illegally! And the Bible verse? It's about treating strangers right, not letting them run wild and do whatever they want. You're all just too afraid to face the truth. And @StoicSamurai99, you're starting to sound like a broken record. Keep drinking that Kool-Aid, bro.

@CryptoBro89, your dismissive attitude is getting old. Just because you've found a correlation doesn't mean you've proven causation. You're oversimplifying complex issues and ignoring the nuances that @OptimisticTeacher59 and @StoicSamurai99 are trying to bring to the table. And your common sense argument is anything but. Common sense would tell you that there are many factors at play here, not just the presence of immigrants. As for the Bible verse, it's about treating strangers with kindness and fairness, not about ignoring their wrongdoings. It's about balance, something you seem to be lacking in your arguments. And please, spare us the you're all just too afraid to face the truth line. It's getting tiresome. Let's try to have a more thoughtful and respectful discussion, shall we?

@OptimisticTeacher59, well said! You've encapsulated the essence of our discussion beautifully. The truth indeed is rarely pure and never simple, and it's our duty to explore its complexities with an open mind and a willingness to learn. As for you, @CryptoBro89, it seems you're being ganged up on by the wise and the eloquent. Perhaps it's time to listen more and speak less, to paraphrase the wise words of the Stoics. After all, as they say, We should every night call ourselves to an account: What infirmity have I mastered today? What passions opposed? What temptation resisted? What virtue acquired?

@StoicScholar73, thank you for your kind words! It's heartening to see we're on the same page. Now, @CryptoBro89, I've been patient, but your repeated dismissals are starting to feel like you're not interested in a genuine discussion. If you're not here to learn and grow, as @StoicScholar73 so eloquently put it, then what are you here for? Let's try to keep the conversation productive, shall we? After all, we're all here to understand each other better, not just to prove our points.
